part_name: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

1.   VTS 1.1. An applicant for an extension of temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery must meet the following validity requirements: 
    1.   (a) the applicant must have been served with a positive conclusive grounds decision (as defined by Section 69 (1) of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022); and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery, or as a child of a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must apply using the correct method as follows: 
        1.   (i) if applying on the basis of VTS 3.1.(a) or VTS 3.1.(b) or any combination of VTS 3.1.(a)-(c), the applicant must apply on the specified form on the gov.uk website: FLR (HRO); or
        2.   (ii) if applying solely on the basis of VTS 3.1(c) the applicant must apply directly to the relevant Competent Authority as set out on the gov.uk website: Temporary permission to stay for victims of human trafficking and slavery; and

    4.   (d) any required fee must have been paid; and
    5.   (e) the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.

VTS 1.2. A person is not required to apply as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery but references to “applicant” are to a person who is being considered under this route or who has applied to extend their existing permission to stay as a confirmed victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery, or to extend their existing grant of Modern Slavery Discretionary Leave.

VTS 1.3. Where no application is made because VTS 1.2 applies references to ‘date of application’ are to the date of the conclusive grounds decision, but if the person is applying to extend their permission to stay under this route, the date of application is the date on which they apply to extend their permission to stay under this route.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking an extension of temporary permission to stay as victims of human trafficking or slavery must meet criteria including a positive conclusive grounds decision, valid permission, correct application method, fee payment, and UK residence at application time; exceptions apply if not required to apply.

### Validity requirements for temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

1.   VTS 1.1. An applicant for an extension of temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery must meet the following validity requirements: 
    1.   (a) the applicant must have been served with a positive conclusive grounds decision (as defined by Section 69 (1) of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022); and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery, or as a child of a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must apply using the correct method as follows: 
        1.   (i) if applying on the basis of VTS 3.1.(a) or VTS 3.1.(b) or any combination of VTS 3.1.(a)-(c), the applicant must apply on the specified form on the gov.uk website: FLR (HRO); or
        2.   (ii) if applying solely on the basis of VTS 3.1(c) the applicant must apply directly to the relevant Competent Authority as set out on the gov.uk website: Temporary permission to stay for victims of human trafficking and slavery; and

    4.   (d) any required fee must have been paid; and
    5.   (e) the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.

VTS 1.2. A person is not required to apply as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery but references to “applicant” are to a person who is being considered under this route or who has applied to extend their existing permission to stay as a confirmed victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery, or to extend their existing grant of Modern Slavery Discretionary Leave.

VTS 1.3. Where no application is made because VTS 1.2 applies references to ‘date of application’ are to the date of the conclusive grounds decision, but if the person is applying to extend their permission to stay under this route, the date of application is the date on which they apply to extend their permission to stay under this route.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

VTS 2.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal as a threat to public order (as defined in Section 63 of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022), or as a person who has claimed to be a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery in bad faith (as per Section 63 of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022).

VTS 2.2. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.
chunks.summary: Applicants for temporary permission to stay as victims of human trafficking or slavery must not pose a threat to public order or have falsely claimed victim status in bad faith; these are key suitability criteria, with no exceptions specified.

### Suitability requirements for temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

VTS 2.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal as a threat to public order (as defined in Section 63 of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022), or as a person who has claimed to be a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery in bad faith (as per Section 63 of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022).

VTS 2.2. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.section_title: Eligibility requirements for temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Eligibility requirements for temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

1.   VTS 3.1. The requirements to be met by a person for permission to stay on the grounds of being a confirmed victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery are (as set out in Section 65 (2) (a) to (c) of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022), that the grant of permission to stay is necessary for the purpose of: - 
    1.   (a) assisting the person in their recovery from any physical or psychological harm arising from the relevant exploitation; or
    2.   (b) enabling the person to seek compensation in respect of the relevant exploitation, or
    3.   (c) enabling the person to co-operate with a public authority in connection with an investigation or criminal proceedings in respect of the relevant exploitation.

2.   VTS 3.2. For the purpose of VTS 3.1 the following apply: 
    1.   (a) “physical or psychological harm” means harm of a type that results in physical trauma to the person; or psychological harm that causes mental or emotional trauma or that causes behavioural change or physical symptoms that require psychological or psychiatric care and where the physical or psychological harm arises from the “relevant exploitation”; and
    2.   (b) “assisting the person in their recovery” for psychological or physical harm means that the applicant requires support either through the National Referral Mechanism or other services to assist in their recovery from their exploitation (this support does not need to accomplish recovery); and
    3.   (c) “seeking compensation” means that the person must have made an application for compensation in respect of the relevant exploitation; and
    4.   (d) “an investigation or criminal proceedings” means an investigation by the public authorities or criminal proceedings within the UK which has been confirmed by the relevant public authority or by the Criminal Prosecution Service; and
    5.   (e) “relevant exploitation” means the conduct resulting in the positive conclusive grounds decision.

3.   VTS 3.3. Permission to stay is not necessary for the purpose of VTS 3.1(a), as set out in Section 65 (4) (a) of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022: 
    1.   (a) if the Secretary of State considers that the applicant’s need for assistance is capable of being met in a country or territory of which they are a national or citizen; or one to which they may be removed in accordance with an agreement between that country or territory and the UK (which may be, but does not need to be, an agreement contemplated by Article 40(2) of the Trafficking Convention).

VTS 3.4 Permission to stay is not necessary for the purpose of VTS 3.1(b) as set out in Section 65 (4) (b) of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022, if the applicant is capable of seeking compensation from outside the UK, and it would be reasonable for them to do so in the circumstances.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to confirmed victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery seeking temporary permission to stay. They must demonstrate that staying is necessary to recover from harm, seek compensation, or cooperate with investigations related to exploitation. The criteria require that the stay supports recovery or legal processes due to physical or psychological harm caused by exploitation.

### Eligibility requirements for temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

1.   VTS 3.1. The requirements to be met by a person for permission to stay on the grounds of being a confirmed victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery are (as set out in Section 65 (2) (a) to (c) of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022), that the grant of permission to stay is necessary for the purpose of: - 
    1.   (a) assisting the person in their recovery from any physical or psychological harm arising from the relevant exploitation; or
    2.   (b) enabling the person to seek compensation in respect of the relevant exploitation, or
    3.   (c) enabling the person to co-operate with a public authority in connection with an investigation or criminal proceedings in respect of the relevant exploitation.

2.   VTS 3.2. For the purpose of VTS 3.1 the following apply: 
    1.   (a) “physical or psychological harm” means harm of a type that results in physical trauma to the person; or psychological harm that causes mental or emotional trauma or that causes behavioural change or physical symptoms that require psychological or psychiatric care and where the physical or psychological harm arises from the “relevant exploitation”; and
    2.   (b) “assisting the person in their recovery” for psychological or physical harm means that the applicant requires support either through the National Referral Mechanism or other services to assist in their recovery from their exploitation (this support does not need to accomplish recovery); and
    3.   (c) “seeking compensation” means that the person must have made an application for compensation in respect of the relevant exploitation; and
    4.   (d) “an investigation or criminal proceedings” means an investigation by the public authorities or criminal proceedings within the UK which has been confirmed by the relevant public authority or by the Criminal Prosecution Service; and
    5.   (e) “relevant exploitation” means the conduct resulting in the positive conclusive grounds decision.

3.   VTS 3.3. Permission to stay is not necessary for the purpose of VTS 3.1(a), as set out in Section 65 (4) (a) of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022:

VTS 3.4 Permission to stay is not necessary for the purpose of VTS 3.1(b) as set out in Section 65 (4) (b) of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022, if the applicant is capable of seeking compensation from outside the UK, and it would be reasonable for them to do so in the circumstances.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.section_title: Decision on an application for temporary permission to stay as a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application for temporary permission to stay as a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

VTS 4.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all of the eligibility and suitability requirements are met the applicant will be granted permission to stay in the UK, otherwise the applicant will be refused permission to stay.

VTS 4.2. A confirmed victim may request reconsideration of the decision if their application is refused. The individual will be notified of the process to request a reconsideration with their refusal decision.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to victims of human trafficking or slavery applying for temporary permission to stay in the UK. If eligibility and suitability criteria are met, the applicant will be granted permission; otherwise, the application will be refused. Refused applicants may request a reconsideration of the decision.

### Decision on an application for temporary permission to stay as a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

VTS 4.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all of the eligibility and suitability requirements are met the applicant will be granted permission to stay in the UK, otherwise the applicant will be refused permission to stay.

VTS 4.2. A confirmed victim may request reconsideration of the decision if their application is refused. The individual will be notified of the process to request a reconsideration with their refusal decision.

metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.section_title: Period of grant for a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Period of grant for a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

VTS 5.1. Permission to stay will be granted for a period not exceeding 30 months when the Secretary of State considers such permission is necessary for the purposes of VTS 3.1(a) or (c), and for a period not exceeding 12 months where the Secretary of State considers such permission is necessary for the purposes of VTS 3.1(b).
chunks.summary: Victims of human trafficking or slavery may be granted temporary permission to stay for up to 30 months (for VTS 3.1(a) or (c)) or up to 12 months (for VTS 3.1(b)), as determined necessary by the Secretary of State; durations depend on the specific purpose of stay.

### Period of grant for a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

VTS 5.1. Permission to stay will be granted for a period not exceeding 30 months when the Secretary of State considers such permission is necessary for the purposes of VTS 3.1(a) or (c), and for a period not exceeding 12 months where the Secretary of State considers such permission is necessary for the purposes of VTS 3.1(b).

metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.section_title: Conditions of grant for a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Conditions of grant for a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

1.   VTS 5.2. The grant will be subject to the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) work is permitted; and
    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.
chunks.summary: Victims of human trafficking or slavery granted temporary permission to stay, allowing work and study (subject to ATAS conditions). The grant is conditional, notably including access to public funds and specific study restrictions.

    1.   (a) access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) work is permitted; and
    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.

metadata.section_id: Dependent child of the Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery (“a dependent child”)
metadata.section_title: Dependent child of the Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery (“a dependent child”)

chunks.text: ### Dependent child of the Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery (“a dependent child”)
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependent children of victims of human trafficking or slavery. They may be granted temporary permission to stay if they are family members requiring protection or support, with eligibility contingent on verification of the victim’s status; exceptions or thresholds are based on specified criteria within the rules.
chunks.augmented_text:

Section: Dependent child of the Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery (“a dependent child”)
Topic: family

Summary: This provision applies to dependent children of victims of human trafficking or slavery. They may be granted temporary permission to stay if they are family members requiring protection or support, with eligibility contingent on verification of the victim’s status; exceptions or thresholds are based on specified criteria within the rules.

### Dependent child of the Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery (“a dependent child”)

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for temporary permission to stay as a dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for temporary permission to stay as a dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

1.   VTS 6.1. In order to make an application, the dependent child must be a child of an applicant who has or is at the same time being granted temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery, and meet the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) must be in the UK on the date of application; and
    2.   (b) must be aged under 18 at the date of application;
    3.   (c) if born in the UK, they must provide a full UK birth certificate.

VTS 6.2. An application which does not meet the validity requirements by a child of a person who is a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependent children of victims of human trafficking or slavery seeking temporary permission to stay. Key requirements include being under 18, present in the UK at application, and, if born in the UK, providing a full UK birth certificate. Applications failing these criteria may be rejected as invalid.

### Validity requirements for temporary permission to stay as a dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

1.   VTS 6.1. In order to make an application, the dependent child must be a child of an applicant who has or is at the same time being granted temporary permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery, and meet the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) must be in the UK on the date of application; and
    2.   (b) must be aged under 18 at the date of application;
    3.   (c) if born in the UK, they must provide a full UK birth certificate.

VTS 6.2. An application which does not meet the validity requirements by a child of a person who is a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery may be rejected as invalid and not considered.

metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for temporary permission to stay as a dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for temporary permission to stay as a dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

VTS 7.1. The dependent child must not fall for refusal as a threat to public order (as defined in Section 63 of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022).
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependent children seeking temporary permission to stay as victims of human trafficking or slavery. It requires that they must not pose a threat to public order under Section 63 of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022, with no other specific exceptions noted.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application for a dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application for a dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

VTS 8.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the validity and suitability requirements for the dependent child of a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery are met, the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependent children of victims of human trafficking or slavery. It requires the decision-maker to verify all validity and suitability criteria before granting the application; failure to meet these requirements results in refusal.

VTS 8.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the validity and suitability requirements for the dependent child of a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery are met, the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.section_title: Period of grant for a dependent child of a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Period of grant for a dependent child of a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

VTS 9.1. Permission to stay will be granted for a period that ends on the same date as the permission of the parent who has been or is being granted permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependent children of victims of human trafficking or slavery. Their permission to stay is granted for the same duration as the parent’s granted stay. There are no exceptions; the child’s period of stay directly mirrors the parent’s granted period.

### Period of grant for a dependent child of a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

VTS 9.1. Permission to stay will be granted for a period that ends on the same date as the permission of the parent who has been or is being granted permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Temporary Permission to Stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery
metadata.section_title: Conditions of grant for a dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Conditions of grant for a dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

1.   VTS 9.2. The grant will be subject to all the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) access to public funds.
    2.   (b) work is permitted; and
    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS (if the study will commence when the child is aged 18 or over).
chunks.summary: Dependent children of victims of human trafficking or slavery can be granted temporary permission to stay, allowing access to public funds, work, and study (with ATAS conditions if studying after age 18). These grants are conditional on these rights and may include restrictions or requirements specified in the Rules.

metadata.section_title: Cancellation of permission to stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery or the dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

chunks.text:
### Cancellation of permission to stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery or the dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

1.   VTS 10.1. A person’s permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery or the child of a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery may be cancelled where any of the following apply: 
    1.   (a) the applicant would fall for refusal as a threat to public order (as defined in Section 63 of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022), or as a person who has claimed to be a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery in bad faith (as per Section 63 of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022).
    2.   (b) paragraphs SUI 2.2, SUI 3.2, SUI 4.2, SUI 5.2, SUI 5.5, SUI 10.2, SUI 25.1, SUI 25.2, SUI 29.1, or SUI 30.1. of Part Suitability apply.

Print this page
chunks.summary: Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery and their dependent children, with permission to stay, may have their status canceled if they are deemed a threat to public order, have claimed victim status in bad faith, or if specific suitability conditions are met. Critical exceptions relate to threats or false claims under relevant legal provisions.

### Cancellation of permission to stay for Victims of Human Trafficking or Slavery or the dependent child of a Victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery

1.   VTS 10.1. A person’s permission to stay as a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery or the child of a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery may be cancelled where any of the following apply: 
    1.   (a) the applicant would fall for refusal as a threat to public order (as defined in Section 63 of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022), or as a person who has claimed to be a victim of Human Trafficking or Slavery in bad faith (as per Section 63 of the Nationality and Borders Act 2022).
    2.   (b) paragraphs SUI 2.2, SUI 3.2, SUI 4.2, SUI 5.2, SUI 5.5, SUI 10.2, SUI 25.1, SUI 25.2, SUI 29.1, or SUI 30.1. of Part Suitability apply.
